lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can write sentences (e.g., “Is it an umbrella?”) clearly and accurately in the correct space.
supportStrategies: (Writing) Model writing a sentence from the board: “Is it an umbrella?” Have students copy into their books with correct spacing.
stretchStrategies: Find and Describe Race – Stick flashcards or draw quick item pictures around the room. In pairs, one student finds an item, the other must write a sentence using the correct structure (“It’s a short ruler.”). Set a timer and rotate roles. Emphasise sentence accuracy under pressure.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can listen to spoken descriptions and choose the correct item.
supportStrategies: (Listening) Say a description: “It’s old. It’s a puzzle.” Students point to the matching image in the SB.
stretchStrategies: Find and Describe Race – Stick flashcards or draw quick item pictures around the room. In pairs, one student finds an item, the other must write a sentence using the correct structure (“It’s a short ruler.”). Set a timer and rotate roles. Emphasise sentence accuracy under pressure.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can work together politely and take turns to play a competitive game.
supportStrategies: (4Cs – Turn-taking) In small groups, play a game where students describe an item and take turns guessing which one it is.

items: Unstressed vowels do not really exist in Vietnamese, so these need extra practice. Make sure the final vowel of computer is a light schwa, not a heavy com-pu-TER. Same with the final vowel of banana. Or the second syllable of elephant. And so on.

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
